title: 114_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015" establishes a patient registry for mesothelioma data collection and research under Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including information on incidence, prevalence, treatment outcomes, and hospital disaggregation. The Secretary will develop a patient registry to collect data on mesothelioma in the United States, including treatment outcomes, incidence, prevalence, demographic factors, and factors associated with the disease. The information in the registry will be made available to the public to enhance research and prevention efforts. The Secretary will collect data on mesothelioma in the US, including demographic factors like age, race, gender, and family history. Information from the registry will be available to the public for research and prevention efforts. The United States will collect and store information on mesothelioma, including demographics, risk factors, diagnosis markers, epidemiology, and natural history of the disease. The United States will collect and store information on mesothelioma, including demographics, risk factors, diagnosis markers, epidemiology, prevention, detection, management, treatment approaches, and outcomes measures. The Secretary will consult with experts in epidemiology, disease surveillance, registries, and national voluntary associations. The Secretary will consult with experts in epidemiology, disease surveillance, registries, national voluntary associations, health information technology, clinicians, and research scientists for the mesothelioma registry. The Secretary will consult with experts in epidemiology, disease surveillance, registries, national voluntary associations, health information technology, clinicians, and research scientists for the mesothelioma registry. Clinicians and research scientists with expertise in mesothelioma and translational research will be involved. The Secretary will coordinate with other federal agencies and make information from the registry available to the public while ensuring privacy. The Secretary will make information from the mesothelioma registry available to the public while ensuring stringent privacy protections as per HIPAA laws. Additionally, reports to Congress outlining findings will be submitted within 18 months of the enactment of the Mary Jo Lawyer Spano Mesothelioma Patient Registry Act of 2015.
